Mattias,

Thank you for the thoughtful comments.  These exchanges are very
=
helpful to our thinking about this new method and its promise.

I would not=
 want to imply that novelty search is a panacea (i.e. a
solution to everyth=
ing).  That would be a big mistake and if that is
what we seem to be sugges=
ting, we need to refine our language.

What we mean to suggest is that nove=
lty search will indeed find
solutions (and things that are interesting and =
useful though perhaps
not "solutions" in the typical sense) in many cases w=
here objective
fitness is paralyzed.  In other words, it makes more possibl=
e,
although it does not solve everything.

The concerns you raise are legit=
imate, yet I do not think they are as
grave as you suggest for the followin=
g reasons:

Problem 1:  In fact, the "dimensionality" of a problem with res=
pect to
novelty is a more complicated and nuanced issue than you analysis
i=
mplies.  The maze domain in fact is very high dimensional, not just
2-D.  W=
here are the other dimensions?  They are every single
(x,y,angle) tuple for=
 every tick of the clock that an individual is
active.

It just so happens =
that in the paper we only measured novelty using
the final (x,y).  But that=
 was our decision and does not represent the
dimensionality of the behavior=
 itself.

The interesting thing though is that recently we have been playin=
g
with novelty search where *all* the (x,y) pairs are included in the
behav=
ior characterization and the novelty metric, making it very high
dimensiona=
l.  The big surprise is that in this domain is has no
effect!  We are still=
 getting our heads around this fact.  In other
words, it is aware of the di=
fference between an agent that veers
slightly left, slightly right, zigzags=
, etc., even if they come to the
same endpoint.  And yet, the maze is still=
 solved on average in the
same amount of evaluations as if we had ignored t=
his information. 
It's really quite interesting.

This insight shows that "=
dimensionality" is a multifaceted issue.  You
might then say that somehow t=
he dimensionality of the behavior is not
the issue, but rather the dimensio=
nality of "physical space" is
somehow instrumental in determining the compu=
tational complexity.  And
that is possible: If the maze were 8-dimensional,=
 it would possibly
increase the computation time exponentially.  

Yet on t=
he other hand, what physical-based problem exists in 8
dimensions?  Real wo=
rld problems generally do not take place in 8
dimensional space.  Furthermo=
re, even if adding dimensions does make
things slower, if we end up taking =
a year of exploration to produce
something phenomenal, it isn't really a pr=
oblem that the computation
was expensive.  Rather, you might say that it's =
a *good* thing that we
have a method that can actually leverage that much c=
omputation to
produce a solution, as opposed to fitness, which is lost rega=
rdless of
how long we wait.  

There is obviously some fundamental issue st=
ill beyond our
intellectual grasp here, because the dimensionality of physi=
cal space
seems to be a superficial concept that is not fundamental to sear=
ch. 
Yet the dimensionality of the maze domain is hundreds of dimensions if=

we take all points crossed into account, and doing that has no effect
on p=
erformance.  So we need to figure out what really matters and why-
a very i=
nteresting subject.

My hunch right now is that one of the factors that mak=
es
high-dimension behavior space tractable is complexification and the
stru=
cture of the behavior space itself, which is a property of the
genotype->ph=
enotype map.  In fact, it is possible the situation is
significantly more p=
alatable than you are guessing because novelty
search with something like N=
EAT moves from simple to complex networks.

Within the simple space of low-=
dimensional neural networks, in fact,
there are not that many novel behavio=
rs after all.  Just because the
space of all *conceivable* behaviors is pot=
entially vast does not mean
that they all exist in the space of the simple =
network. 

Then, when networks complexify, only a few new types of behavior=
 open
up at a time, and these tend to be related to their simpler
predecess=
or behaviors.  So in other words, we are climbing the ladder
of complexity,=
 which means that, if the desired behavior is not some
kind of radical irre=
gular high-entropy mess, we are going to cross the
solution well before we =
ascend too high on the ladder.  Thus, just as
with fitness, novelty search =
benefits from complexification.

It helps to look at nature this way too.  =
It would be hard to believe
if you showed me a single cell in a petri dish =
that all of nature on
earth would descend from it, including humanity itsel=
f, if I wait long
enough.  Yet it would be true.  And you might argue that =
it is simply
not possible because the space of phenotypes is so vast and fu=
ll of
endless offshoots that go nowhere.  Yet that argument would be missin=
g
the fact that nature complexifies.  We don't start out in the space of
al=
l phenotypes.  We start with a few good ones and elaborate on the
initial t=
hemes.

Not to mention indirect encoding: it tends to establish useful
regu=
larities and then exploit and exploit them.  So novelty search can
go down =
such paths as well.

Thus the situation currently *appears* less grave than=
 you suggest,
yet at the same time, there is so much that is not well under=
stood
that I would still hedge my bets.  But certainly it is an exciting
op=
portunity to explore and learn more.

Problem 2:  Again, technically it cou=
ld happen that you walk down a
trail a while then get diverted and never ca=
n come back through the
same point, but I think in practice that is probabl=
y not a big problem. 

I like to think of the population as hot air in a ba=
lloon looking to
get out.  If it can't find a hole to escape, it will churn=
 and churn.
 And the more it churns, the more inhospitable the balloon beco=
mes,
because points keep getting added to the archive, making it denser and=

denser.  Eventually, some particles will bust through a hole.  It may
not =
be the hole that you are referring to as "blocked," but it may
nevertheless=
 lead to the same higher place (I would guess in real
world problems there =
is rarely only one path to get from A to B).  

Even if there is only one g=
ood path, let us say for some reason that
novelty search was repelled from =
going back through it.  In that case,
the balloon is filling up with archiv=
e points and it's getting more
and more high-pressure in there.  Eventually=
, the area of the path
that was covered is still less dense than the rest o=
f the trapped air,
and it will suddenly shoot down that path even though it=
 was once
visited before.  With novelty search, eventually, the path once t=
aken
becomes the path less taken, and thus becomes an attractor again.

So =
evolution will not get stuck at a dead end.  Rather, it will slosh
around g=
etting more and more frantic until it breaks free.  

Another thing to reme=
mber is that these paths in the maze are not hard
constraints on where you =
can go through mutation.  A single mutation
can move you from one side of a=
 "wall" to another.  Thus there is more
freedom than meets the eye because =
of stochasticity.

None of these arguments proves anything, of course.  The=
y are just
stories of what may happen.  But they show that the frailty or p=
ower
of the methodology in general is still quite an open question that
nee=
ds to be explored further to be settled.  Of course, I am guessing
there wi=
ll be some very interesting discoveries, but that's just my hunch.

Finally=
, by all means please share any criticism or concern that comes
to mind.  T=
here's no harm in this kind of intellectual exchange and
there is no need t=
o apologize.  In fact, it's very productive.   I am
expecting a great deal =
of dubiousness to novelty search.  After all,
you can't go and tell an audi=
ence of evolutionary computation
scientists to give up fitness functions an=
d expect a standing ovation :)

ken
